awd_titl_txt: Curved, Twisted and Doped Nanocarbons: Stepwise Build-Up of Charge and Metal Intercalation
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Marina Petrukhina of the State University of New York (SUNY) at Albany is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program of the Division of Chemistry to study a diverse set of nanocarbon materials with inherent curvature and twist. Nanocarbon materials are increasingly being used in a range of applications, particularly as electrodes in alternative energy generation and storage systems such as Li-ion batteries and supercapacitors. It is now generally agreed that the charge storage and transport properties of these materials are highly dependent on the structural features of their molecules and assemblies. The project is poised to advance fundamental knowledge on the chemical and electronic properties of these non-planar molecular nanocarbons. A better understanding of these systems and their multi-electron acquisition and charge transport processes paves the way for their utilization in practical energy devices. Beyond its fundamental importance, a major objective of the project is the enhancement of the educational and research experiences of graduate and undergraduate students at the SUNY Albany to prepare them for future success in a highly competitive workforce environment.  The PI is actively involved in enhancing the infrastructure across the State University of New York (SUNY) campuses to strengthen the research portfolio and to facilitate innovation in nanoscience, sustainability and energy related fields. 

The project is carrying out a broad fundamental investigation of stepwise chemical reduction processes and multi-electron storage capacities of a diverse set of novel nanocarbon materials. The project's three main objectives are: 1) the evaluation of the structural transformations of curved, twisted, and doped molecular nanographenes with different core topologies and pi-conjugation upon addition of multiple electrons; (2) the investigation of the reduction-induced reactivity and utilization of intra- and intermolecular C−C coupling reactions for the synthesis of new extended polyaromatic systems; and 3) the study of self-assembly and alkali metal intercalation of the highly charged carbon scaffolds with embedded cavities and pockets for the development of new energy-storage materials. The project provides new insights into electron acquisition abilities and reactivity of novel molecular nanocarbons with contorted and strained frameworks, as well as uncovers unusual structural transformations and new coupling pathways upon stepwise build-up of negative charge. By improving the fundamental understanding of the redox properties, self-assembly and alkali metal intercalation processes, the project facilitates practical applications of the nanostructured carbon materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Marina A. Petrukhina (PI) NSF Award CHE-2003411: Curved, Twisted and Doped Nanocarbons: Stepwise Build-Up of Charge and Metal Intercalation, $479,997 (direct and indirect costs) 9/01/2020 - 8/31/2024.

Intellectual Merits

With the funds provided by the National Science Foundation CHE-2003411 award, a broad fundamental program to study a diverse set of nanocarbon materials with inherent curvature and twist has been established at the Department of Chemistry, University at Albany, NY. This program unveils multi-electron acquisition properties of novel nanocarbon hosts having different core topologies by systematic investigation of their structural and electronic responses towards multi-electron charging. During the award period, the developed synthetic protocols allowed the preparation of a wide range of novel stepwise reduced products coupled with their full characterization by X-ray diffraction, spectroscopic and theoretical tools. This study revealed original responses to gradual electron addition which are core- and charge-dependent. The project advances fundamental knowledge on the chemical and electronic properties of a great variety of non-planar molecular nanocarbons and provides new insights for their utilization as new ligand-transfer and energy storage materials.

The results have been reported in 35 research manuscripts and one major review published since 2020 in a variety of peer-reviewed scientific journals. Among those are Nat. Chem. (1), JACS (3), Angew. Chem. (7), Chem. Sci. (7), Chem. Commun. (2), Chem. Eur. J. (3), Org. Chem. Front. (2), Inorg. Chem. (2), Cryst. Growth. Des. (2), Eur. J. Org. Chem. (1), J. Phys. Org. Chem. (1), J. Organomet. Chem. (1) and Organometallics (3) manuscripts, several of which were selected as Very Important or Hot Papers and highlighted on journal covers. We also contributed a comprehensive review (Coord. Chem. Rev. 2023) and an invited Perspective (Chem. Sci. 2023). The results were broadly disseminated by the PI and graduate students at multiple National and Regional ACS meetings, as well as at several international and interdisciplinary conferences.

Broader Impacts

This fundamental research program provided insights into electronic accepting abilities and alkali metal intercalation patterns of novel nanocarbon hosts, which is important for design of new carbon-based anode materials for Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. As a result, this program has advanced the development of materials chemistry of curved nanocarbon scaffolds and promoted applications of alkali metal-doped carbonaceous materials in the technologically important field of energy storage. Using the results obtained in this experimental program, the PI has completed two successful APS ANL (Argonne National Lab) grant applications that allowed access to synchrotron facilities. This provided advanced research and professional training opportunities for graduate students in the group. In addition, the multi-year PI involvement in planning of the new Emerging Technology and Entrepreneurship Complex (ETEC) was rewarded by a completion of this unique and ambitious project in 2021. The relocation of the PI's laboratories to ETEC in 2022 had great impact on the expansion of the institutional resources at the University at Albany campus and provided new research opportunities for the PI's group.

During the above research activities, an educational program was created for training young chemists who became proficient in organic and inorganic synthesis, crystal growth, X-ray diffraction and variable spectroscopic techniques. The program participants also developed good writing and presentation skills as well as understanding of current needs and challenges of carbon-based nanomaterials and their broad applications. This project has been used to train several graduate and undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral associate. Over the reported period three students have successfully graduated (2 Ph.D. and 1 M.S. student, who is an active U.S. National Guard). One Ph.D. student was recognized by a very competitive UAlbany Distinguished Doctoral Dissertation Award and one selected as the Future Leader Speaker for the ENY ACS Series. All graduate students participating in this NSF-supported program co-authored multiple research manuscripts and delivered multiple presentations at the local, regional and National ACS meetings and international conference. From several undergraduates trained within this NSF-program, three now continue their graduate education in Chemistry. Overall, this program made its major impact on the enhancement of educational and research experiences for graduate and undergraduate students at UAlbany by engaging them into a modern cross-disciplinary research program, and thus preparing them for their successful careers in science.
